squads for 2017/18 Premier League confirmed |publisher=Premier League |date=2 February 2018 |accessdate=10 February 2018}}</ref> | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1989|10|30|df=y}}<ref>{{cite book birth_place = [[Bath, Somerset|Bath]], England | height = {{convert|1.86|m|order=flip}}<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.burnleyfootballclub.com/teams/first-team/forward/ashley-barnes/ |title=Ashley Barnes |publisher=Burnley F.C. |accessdate=5 February 2019}}</ref> | position = [[Forward (association football)#Striker|Striker]] | currentclub = [[Burnley F.C.|Burnley]] | clubnumber = 10 | | caps2 = 22 | goals2 = 2 | years3 = 2007 | clubs3 = → [[Oxford United F.C.|Oxford United]] (loan) | caps3 = 3 | goals3 = 1 | years4 = 2008 | clubs4 = → [[Salisbury City F.C.|Salisbury City]] (loan) | caps4 = 5 | goals4 = 0 | years5 = 2008–2009 | clubs5 = → [[Eastbourne Borough F.C.|Eastbourne Borough]] (loan) | caps5 = 8 | goals5 = 5 | years6 = 2010 | clubs6 = → [[Torquay United F.C.|Torquay United]] (loan) | caps6 = 6 | goals6 = 0 | years7 = 2010 | clubs7 = → [[Brighton & Hove Albion F.C.|Brighton & Hove Albion]] (loan) | caps7 = 8 | goals7 = 4 | years8 = 2010–2014 | clubs8 = [[Brighton & Hove Albion F.C.|Brighton & Hove Albion]] | caps8 = 141 | goals8 = 42 | years9 = 2014– | clubs9 = [[Burnley F.C.|Burnley]] | caps9 = 156 | goals9 = 32 | nationalyears1 = 2008 | nationalteam1 = Austria U20 | nationalcaps1 = 1 | nationalgoals1 = 0 | club-update = 18:08, 2 March 2019 (UTC) }} '''Ashley Luke Barnes''' (born 30 October 1989) is a professional [[Association football|footballer]] who plays as a [[Forward (association football)#Striker|striker]] for [[Premier League]] club [[Burnley F.C.|Burnley]].
Barnes previously played for [[Paulton Rovers F.C.|Paulton Rovers]], [[Plymouth Argyle F.C.|Plymouth Argyle]], [[Oxford United F.C.|Oxford United]], [[Salisbury City F.C.|Salisbury City]], [[Eastbourne Borough F.C.|Eastbourne Borough]], [[Torquay United F.C.|Torquay United]] and [[Brighton & Hove Albion F.C.|Brighton & Hove Albion]]. He has been [[Cap (sport)|capped]] by Austria at international level, making one appearance for their [[Austria national under-21 football team|under-20]] team.
==Club career== ===Early career and Plymouth Argyle=== As a child, Barnes played on a team called Bath Arsenal, where his teammates included fellow future professional [[Scott Sinclair]].<ref name=hunter/> He began his senior career as a prolific goalscorer with local club [[Paulton Rovers F.C.|Paulton Rovers]] of the [[Southern Football League|Southern League]]. He had an extended trial with Championship club [[Plymouth Argyle F.C.|Plymouth Argyle]] in March 2007, and sufficiently impressed to be awarded with an eighteen-month contract by the club, having scored several goals for the reserve team.<ref>{{cite news |title=Paulton striker impresses Argyle |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/p/plymouth_argyle/6347653.stm |publisher=BBC Sport |date=9 February 2007 |accessdate=1 October 2008}}</ref> He made his Plymouth debut in the first round of the [[2007–08 Football League Cup|League Cup]] in August 2007 against [[Wycombe Wanderers F.C.|Wycombe Wanderers]], coming on as a substitute for first-team regular [[Sylvan Ebanks-Blake]].<ref>{{cite news |title=Plymouth 2–1 Wycombe |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/league_cup/6941834.stm |publisher=BBC Sport |date=14 August 2007 |accessdate=1 October 2008}}</ref>
He subsequently found first-team opportunities hard to come by, and was sent on loan to [[Football Conference|Conference]] side [[Oxford United F.C.|Oxford United]] in November 2007 to gain some experience.<ref>{{cite news |title=Oxford sign deadline day strikers |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/o/oxford_utd/7107832.stm |publisher=BBC Sport |date=22 November 2007 |accessdate=1 October 2008}}</ref> Barnes featured five times for Oxford United, including two [[FA Cup]] ties against [[Southend United F.C.|Southend United]], before returning to Plymouth. He was sent out on loan again in March 2008 to another Conference club, this time to [[Salisbury City F.C.|Salisbury City]].<ref>{{cite news |title=Salisbury bring in Barnes on loan |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/s/salisbury/7285607.stm |publisher=BBC Sport |date=8 March 2008 |accessdate=1 October 2008}}</ref> He featured in five league matches for the club but did not find the back of the net.
Barnes was loaned out for a third time in November 2008 to [[Eastbourne Borough F.C.|Eastbourne Borough]], with teammate [[Dan Smith (footballer born 1989)|Daniel Smith]].<ref>{{cite news |date=27 November 2008 |url=http://www.pafc.premiumtv.co.uk/page/NewsDetail/0,,10364~1468498,00.html |archive-url=https://archive.is/20120805150108/http://www.pafc.premiumtv.co.uk/page/NewsDetail/0,,10364~1468498,00.html |dead-url=yes |archivedate=5 August 2012 |title=On the way |publisher=pafc.co.uk |accessdate=27 November 2008}}</ref> He impressed enough for his loan to be extended by a month,<ref>{{cite news |date=5 January 2009 |url=http://www.pafc.co.uk/page/NewsDetail/0,,10364~1509471,00.html |title=Loan extension |publisher=pafc.co.uk |accessdate=6 January 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090430225040/http://www.pafc.co.uk/page/NewsDetail/0%2C%2C10364~1509471%2C00.html |archivedate=30 April 2009}}</ref> before he was recalled by Plymouth Argyle in January 2009, ahead of the club's match against [[Bristol City F.C.|Bristol City]].<ref>{{cite news |date=27 January 2009 |url=http://www.pafc.co.uk/page/NewsDetail/0,,10364~1534218,00.html |title=Ashley called back |publisher=pafc.co.uk |accessdate=28 January 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110722181904/http://www.pafc.co.uk/page/NewsDetail/0%2C%2C10364~1534218%2C00.html |archivedate=22 July 2011}}</ref> He made his league debut for the Pilgrims against [[Wolverhampton Wanderers F.C.|Wolves]] at [[Molineux Stadium|Molineux]], scoring his first goal for the club against [[Coventry City F.C.|Coventry City]]. His performances at the back-end of the [[2008–09 in English football|2008–09 season]] were rewarded when he signed a two-year contract extension in May 2009.<ref>{{cite news |date=6 May 2009 |url=http://www.pafc.co.uk/page/NewsDetail/0,,10364~1645008,00.html |title=New deal for Ash |publisher=pafc.co.uk |accessdate=14 February 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090509085952/http://www.pafc.co.uk/page/NewsDetail/0%2C%2C10364~1645008%2C00.html |archivedate=9 May 2009}}</ref>
He joined [[EFL League Two|League Two]] club [[Torquay United F.C.|Torquay United]] on loan until the end of the season in February 2010,<ref>{{cite news |date=9 February 2010 |url=http://www.pafc.co.uk/page/NewsDetail/0,,10364~1960089,00.html |title=Ash To Plainmoor |publisher=pafc.co.uk |accessdate=14 February 2010 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100212051251/http://www.pafc.co.uk/page/NewsDetail/0%2C%2C10364~1960089%2C00.html |archivedate=12 February 2010 |deadurl=yes}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |date=10 February 2010 |url=http://www.skysports.com/story/0,19528,12875_5935039,00.html |title=Barnes capture delights Buckle |publisher=skysports.com |accessdate=14 February 2010 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100317023657/http://www.skysports.com/story/0%2C19528%2C12875_5935039%2C00.html |archivedate=17 March 2010 |deadurl=no}}</ref> but returned a month later having made six appearances.<ref>{{cite news |date=12 March 2010 |url=http://www.pafc.co.uk/page/NewsDetail/0,,10364~1991607,00.html |title=Barnesy back |publisher=pafc.co.uk |accessdate=12 March 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100315125536/http://www.pafc.co.uk/page/NewsDetail/0%2C%2C10364~1991607%2C00.html |archivedate=15 March 2010}}</ref>
===Brighton & Hove Albion=== [[File:Ashley Barnes Brighton.jpg|thumb|upright|Barnes playing for [[Brighton & Hove Albion F.C.|Brighton & Hove Albion]] in 2011]]
Barnes subsequently joined [[EFL League One|League One]] club [[Brighton & Hove Albion F.C.|Brighton & Hove Albion]] on loan until the end of the season.<ref>{{cite news |date=25 March 2010 |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/b/brighton/8587183.stm |title=Brighton make double loan signing |publisher=BBC Sport |accessdate=2 April 2010 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100328175237/http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/b/brighton/8587183.stm |archivedate=28 March 2010 |deadurl=no}}</ref> He scored on his debut against [[Tranmere Rovers F.C.|Tranmere Rovers]] two days later, having been introduced as a substitute ten minutes earlier.<ref>{{cite news |date=27 March 2010 |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_div_2/8568156.stm |title=Brighton 3–0 Tranmere |publisher=BBC Sport |accessdate=2 April 2010 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100401054052/http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_div_2/8568156.stm |archivedate=1 April 2010 |deadurl=no}}</ref>
On 8 July 2010, Barnes signed a two-year contract with Brighton & Hove Albion after transferring for an undisclosed fee from Plymouth Argyle.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.seagulls.co.uk/page/Latest/0,,10433~2086784,00.html |title=Barnes is back |publisher=Brighton & Hove Albion F.C. |date=8 July 2010 |accessdate=8 July 2010 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100710184325/http://www.seagulls.co.uk/page/Latest/0%2C%2C10433~2086784%2C00.html |archivedate=10 July 2010 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy-all}}</ref> On 12 April 2011, he scored the decisive goal in a 4–3 win at home against [[Dagenham & Redbridge F.C.|Dagenham & Redbridge]], which confirmed their promotion to the [[EFL Championship|Championship]].<ref>{{cite web |last=Fletcher |first=Paul |title=Brighton 4–3 Dag & Red |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/12968187.stm |publisher=BBC Sport |accessdate=13 April 2011 |date=11 April 2011 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110413033537/http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/12968187.stm |archivedate=13 April 2011 |deadurl=no}}</ref> Barnes finished the season as Brighton's second-top goalscorer behind [[Glenn Murray]], with 20 goals in 49 appearances.
In the [[2011-12 Football League Championship|2011–12 season]] Barnes remained a first-choice striker for Brighton's return to the Championship. He finished the season as Brighton's leading goalscorer with 14 goals in all competitions, 11 in the league.
On 9 March 2013, Barnes received a red card in stoppage time against [[Bolton Wanderers F.C.|Bolton Wanderers]] for attempting to trip up the referee. He was subsequently handed a seven-match suspension by [[the Football Association]].<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/21804556 |title=Ashley Barnes: FA extends striker's ban to seven games |publisher=BBC Sport |date=15 March 2013}}</ref> Fans and manager [[Gus Poyet]] were critical of Barnes for this action as it left the club with only one senior striker available to play, as [[Craig Mackail-Smith]] and [[Will Hoskins]] were already injured for the rest of the season. On his return from the ban on 20 April, Barnes scored two goals in a 6–1 win over [[Blackpool F.C.|Blackpool]] and was named man of the match.
===Burnley=== On 10 January 2014, Barnes joined [[Burnley F.C.|Burnley]] for an undisclosed fee on a three-and-a-half-year deal.<ref>{{cite web |title=Burnley sign Barnes from Brighton |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/25681552 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=10 January 2014 |accessdate=10 January 2014}}</ref> On 8 November, he scored the only goal at [[Turf Moor]] to defeat [[Hull City A.F.C.|Hull City]] and gain Burnley's first win of the [[Premier League]] season.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Abraham |first1=Timothy |title=Burnley 1–0 Hull |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/29860234 |accessdate=8 November 2014 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=8 November 2014}}</ref> He scored a second goal on 13 December, the sole goal in a home victory over [[Southampton F.C.|Southampton]] to take Burnley out of the relegation zone.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Sanghera |first1=Mandeep |title=Burnley 1–0 Southampton |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/30357668 |accessdate=14 December 2014 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=13 December 2014}}</ref>
In February 2015, Barnes performed a high tackle on [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea's]] [[Nemanja Matić]], who was sent off for pushing him in retaliation. Barnes did not receive a booking for the challenge, and [[The FA]] confirmed that they would not take retrospective action as that was not normal procedure for attempted tackles.<ref>{{cite news |title=Ashley Barnes escapes FA disciplinary action over horror tackle on Nemanja Matic |url=https://www.independent.ie/sport/soccer/premier-league/ashley-barnes-escapes-fa-disciplinary-action-over-horror-tackle-on-nemanja-matic-31014780.html |accessdate=24 February 2019 |work=Irish Independent |date=23 February 2015}}</ref> Barnes was publicly criticised by Chelsea manager [[José Mourinho]], and said of the criticism "I found that hilarious".<ref name=hunter>{{cite news |last1=Hunter |first1=Andy |title=Ashley Barnes: ‘I got a text saying Mourinho had gone on TV to criticise me. I found it funny’ |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2015/apr/10/ashley-barnes-burnley-jose-mourinho-matic-chelsea-arsenal |accessdate=24 February 2019 |work=The Guadian |date=10 April 2015}}</ref>
On 24 May 2015, as relegated Burnley finished the season with a win over [[Aston Villa F.C.|Aston Villa]], Barnes was taken off with knee cruciate ligament injuries, which would rule him out for the majority of [[2015–16 Football League Championship|the following campaign]].<ref>{{cite news |title=Ashley Barnes: Burnley striker to miss most of next season |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/32908544 |accessdate=28 May 2015 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=27 May 2015}}</ref>
On 3 March 2018, he wrote himself into the history books, scoring his 16th goal in the Premier League to secure a 2–1 victory for Burnley against [[Everton F.C.|Everton]]. His 16th goal, and his 6th of the season, made him Burnley's leading scorer in the [[Premier League]] since it was formed in 1992.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/43178518 |title=Burnley 2–1 Everton |date=3 March 2018 |publisher= |via=www.bbc.co.uk}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.whoscored.com/Players/33386/History/Ashley-Barnes |title=Ashley Barnes – History |website=www.whoscored.com}}</ref>
==International career== Born in Bath to English parents, Barnes would qualify to represent [[Austria]] courtesy of his paternal grandmother, who was from [[Klagenfurt]] if he were to acquire Austrian citizenship.<ref name="Austria">{{cite web |title=Burnley striker Ashley Barnes admits desire to play for Austria |url=http://www.hitc.com/en-gb/2017/03/10/mn-burnley-striker-ashley-barnes-admits-desire-to-play-for-austr/ |publisher=HITC |date=20 March 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |date=1 August 2008 |url=http://paultonroversafc.co.uk/joomla/content/view/63/1/ |title=Ash Called Up For Austria |publisher=paultonroversafc.co.uk |accessdate=14 February 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110824034227/http://paultonroversafc.co.uk/joomla/content/view/63/1/ |archivedate=24 August 2011}}</ref> He was spotted by Austrian officials while on a pre-season tour with Plymouth Argyle in July 2008, and as a result he was called up to their [[Austria national under-21 football team|Under-20 team]] to face [[Switzerland national under-21 football team|Switzerland]] on 19 August 2008, the match was part of a four nation friendly tournament featuring Austria, Germany, Italy, and Switzerland.<ref>{{cite web |title=ÖFB MEDIAINFO 137/2008: FRANZÖSISCHE REFEREES BEI ITALIEN VS ÖSTERREICH/DIE ÖFB KADERLISTEN FÜR U20, U21 UND A-TEAM PLUS TERMINE FÜR DIE KOMMENDEN LÄNDERSPIELE |url=http://www.oefb.at/show_berichtdetail.php?ber_id=11455 |publisher=OFB |accessdate=22 April 2014 |language=German |date=August 2008|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160924002546/http://www.oefb.at/show_berichtdetail.php?ber_id=11455|archive-date=24 September 2016|dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all}}</ref> Barnes made his debut as a substitute in the 73rd minute replacing [[FC Wacker Innsbruck (2002)|FC Wacker Innsbruck's]] [[Julius Perstaller]] in front of 250 spectators.<ref>{{cite web |title=VIELE CHANCEN, ABER DIE SCHWEIZ TRIFFT |url=http://www.oefb.at/show_berichtdetail.php?ber_id=11550 |publisher=OFB |accessdate=22 April 2014 |language=German |date=August 2008|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160924002602/http://www.oefb.at/show_berichtdetail.php?ber_id=11550|archive-date=24 September 2016|dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all}}</ref>
Barnes said in April 2015 that he had had no further contact with the [[Austrian Football Association]], and stated that he was open to representing either England or Austria at senior level if given the opportunity.<ref name=hunter/> In March 2017, whilst playing in the [[Premier League]] for Burnley, he expressed his desire to represent the [[Austria national football team|national senior side]].<ref name="Austria"/> His form in the 2017–18 season led to calls in Austria for him to receive a national team call-up, and manager [[Franco Foda]] confirmed in March 2018 that he was monitoring Barnes.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.espn.co.uk/football/austria/story/3403243/burnley-striker-ashley-barnes-being-monitored-by-austria-franco-foda |title=Austria coach monitoring Burnley's Barnes |date=2 March 2018 |website=ESPN.com}}</ref>
==Personal life== Barnes is from [[Dunkerton, Somerset]], near Bath.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.westerndailypress.co.uk/Delighted-Barnes-sets-sights-flight-Brighton/story-12305135-detail/story.html |title=Delighted Barnes sets sights on top flight with Brighton |date=21 April 2011 |publisher=Western Daily Press |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140503203332/http://www.westerndailypress.co.uk/Delighted-Barnes-sets-sights-flight-Brighton/story-12305135-detail/story.html |archivedate=3 May 2014 |df=dmy-all}}</ref> He attended [[Writhlington School]], near Bath.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.writhlington.org.uk/sixth-form/alumni/ |title=Alumni – Writhlington School |website=www.writhlington.org.uk}}</ref>
==Career statistics== {{updated|match played 2 March 2019}}
